title: Wolf and Lamb
body: Wolf once saw Lamb who had wandered away from the flock. He did not want to rush upon Lamb and seize him violently. Instead, he sought a reasonable complaint to justify his hatred.'You insulted me last year, when you were small', said Wolf. Lamb replied,'How could I have insulted you last year? I'm not even a year old.' Wolf continued,'Well, are you not cropping the grass of this field which belongs to me?' Lamb said,'No, I haven't eaten any grass; I have not even begun to graze.' Finally Wolf exclaimed,'But didn't you drink from the fountain which I drink from?' Lamb answered,'It is my mother's breast that gives me my drink.' Wolf then seized Lamb and as he chewed he said,'You are not going to make this Wolf go without his dinner, even if you are able to easily refute every one of my charges!

moral.text: This fable's moral is implicit in the narrative

Lamb answered,'It is my mother's breast that gives me my drink.'
Wolf then seized Lamb and as he chewed he said,'You are not going to make this Wolf go without his dinner, even if you are able to easily refute every one of my charges!

title: City Mouse and Country Mouse
body: 'City Mouse once happened to pay a visit to the house of Country Mouse where he was served a humble meal of acorns. City Mouse finished his business in the country, and by means of insistent invitations he persuaded Country Mouse to come pay him a visit. City Mouse then brought Country Mouse into a room that was overflowing with food. As they were feasting on various delicacies, a butler opened the door. City Mouse quickly concealed himself in a familiar Mouse-hole, but the poor Country Mouse was not acquainted with the house and frantically scurried around the floorboards, frightened out of his wits. When the butler had taken what he needed, he closed the door behind him. City Mouse then urged Country Mouse to sit back down to dinner. Country Mouse refused and said,'How could I possibly do that? Oh, how scared I am! Do you think that the man is going to comeback?' This was all that the terrified Mouse was able to say. City Mouse insisted,'My dear fellow, you could never find such delicious food as this anywhere else in the world. Acorns are enough for me,' Country Mouse maintained,'so long as I am secure in my freedom!'

moral.text: It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.

title: Fox and the Grapes
body: Driven by hunger, Fox tried to reach some grapes hanging high on the vine. Although she leaped with all her strength, she couldn't manage to reach the grapes. As she went away, Fox remarked,'Oh, you aren't even ripe yet! I don't need any sour grapes.

moral.text: People who speak disparagingly of things that they cannot attain would do well to apply this instructive little story to their own lives.

title: Wolf and Crane
body: 'Wolf swallowed a bone which got stuck in his throat. The pain was excruciating, so Wolf started looking for someone who could be induced to remove the accursed thing in exchange for a reward. Wolf asked each of the animals if they would help him, and finally Crane was convinced by Wolf's solemn promises. Trusting her long beak to Wolf's gaping maw, Crane carried out the dangerous cure. Yet when Crane demanded the promised reward, Wolf simply said,'You ungrateful creature! You extracted your head unharmed from my mouth and still you ask for a reward?'

moral.text: If you think a scoundrel will reward you for a job well done, you are making two mistakes: first, you are helping someone who doesn't deserve it, and second, you will be lucky to escape unharmed.

title: Lion and Mouse on His Mane
body: While Lion was sleeping, Mouse ran over his shaggy mane. This angered Lion and he leaped up from his den, all the hairs of his mane standing on end. Fox made fun of the fact that Lion, king of all the animals, had been startled by Mouse. Lion answered Fox,'You insolent creature! I was not afraid of Mouse'scratching me and running away; I was just worried that he might make a mess on my mane.'

moral.text: This fable's moral is implicit in the narrative and concerns.

title: Fox and Goat in the Well
body: Fox had unwittingly fallen down a well and found herself trapped inside its high walls. Meanwhile, a thirsty Goat had made his way to that same place and asked Fox whether the water was fresh and plentiful. Fox set about laying her trap.'Come down, my friend,' said Fox.'The water is so good that I cannot get enough of it myself!' The bearded billy-Goat lowered himself into the well, whereupon that little vixen leaped up on his lofty horns and emerged from the hole, leaving Goat stuck inside the watery prison.

moral.text: As soon as someone clever gets into trouble, he tries to find a way out at someone else's expense.
